comment._content:
Here is Circular Quay in 1892 - Spot The Differences -

[http://www.flickr.com/photos/powerhouse_museum/2376887996/]PhM

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content:
This one is slightly earlier than 1892 - they are building the Manly and Watsons Bay wharves - 

[http://www.flickr.com/photos/anmm_thecommons/8101595326/]

comment.author: 33147718@N05
comment._content: Thanks Beachcomber, a new fence, some different horses, some spooky moving people... I think between construction of the Manly wharf and the finer details (like the fence along the water) that this is 1891, an article in the SMH of December 1891 mentions the 'new Manly wharf' at the foot of Phillip St. Looking over notes from the original negative, the vessel moored closest to front IS TORRIDON - which I see you already suggested!
comment.authorname: Australian National Maritime Museum on The Commons

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/anmm_thecommons] Aha! The shadows are comparatively short with the sun in the west, implying a summer afternoon - whereas the PhM 1892 photo shadows are longer implying winter. The TORRIDON arrived in Sydney 23/11/1891 - trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/article/13856766 Departed 14/2/1892 - trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/article/13855859 Loaded and cleared with "8006 bales of wool and rough cargo" ... "in great order and trim" ... "Captain [Andrew] Mearns in command" ... - trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/article/13862139 I reckon due to the shadows and shipping dates, and the new Manly wharf, January / February 1892. Now to work out which Orient liner that is ...

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: More info about the TORRIDON's cargo in February 1892, just for interest - "The ship Torridon also cleared at the Customs to-day for London with 8006 bales of wool, 3207 ingots dross, 2075 bags zinc ashes, 600 bags copper ore, 105 tons alumite." from - trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/article/13862175

comment.author: 33147718@N05
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] Wow thanks for all the info - we're down to the real business now re shadows and seasons.
comment.authorname: Australian National Maritime Museum on The Commons

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/anmm_thecommons] Apologies! I get a bit geeky with Circular Quay photos, and I don't know why! I think the ship at left is the R.M.S. AUSTRAL (Orient Line). Two funnels, four masts, and three spars on the foremast. She arrived in Sydney on 18 January 1892 - trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/article/13850616 And departed for London 1 February 1892 - trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/article/13849485 carrying " ... 2305 bales wool, 13 bales basils, 27 casks tallow, 2902 cases preserved meats, 2241 carcasses mutton, 13,800 bars silver-lead bullion, 31 quarter-casks wine, and 19 packages sundries. ... ". And passengers So this photo is likely to be 18-31 January 1892.

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content:
We have met the R.M.S. AUSTRAL 10 years previously, sunk in Neutral Bay - 

[http://www.flickr.com/photos/anmm_thecommons/7237989194/]

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: From a little to the left of this photo, Arthur Streeton "Circular Quay" 1892 (same year) - click through to the hi-res image - commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Arthur_Streeton_-_Circula...

comment.author: 51979177@N02
comment._content: nla.gov.au/nla.news-article71223763 T&CJ pic of Hill Clark & Co's store in 1895 nla.gov.au/nla.news-article64035874 in 1884 acms.sl.nsw.gov.au/item/itemDetailPaged.aspx?itemID=421243 an earlier view of the wool stores on East Circular Quay.

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/51979177@N02] Those wool warehouses along East Circular Quay should provide reliable dating for many old photos - not just when they were built, but also the names of the tenants and businesses,  which seem to vary almost with every image.  The gabled roofs remind me of teeth in a set of dentures!  One photo I came across recently is before 1870 due to the lack of the hip-roofed warehouse seen at extreme right above -

[http://www.flickr.com/photos/state-records-nsw/8579018680/]

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content:
There is also that strange old house clinging precariously to the rock in the gap (see note), with an advert for GERMEA for BREAKFAST painted beside.  Somebody holding out against the Mighty Developers?!  Seen much clearer in this photo than others - thanks Mr Hall!

Memo to self:  find out about the middle ship ....

comment.author: 51979177@N02
comment._content: nla.gov.au/nla.news-article71240578 McBurney, Wallis & Co appear to have moved into the wool store shown here in ca. late 1895 or early 1896. They had their name writ large on the exterior, which makes for a good date marker...link parked here for future reference. nla.gov.au/nla.news-article70457651 this fire in 1870 might have left a gap...[a few hours later - from what I can scrape together from the digitised newspapers, the fire at the Blackwall Stores appears not to have left any lasting gap...I'd say the damaged portion of the stores must have been rebuilt soon after the fire] nla.gov.au/nla.news-article70592536 a view in 1876

comment.author: 33147718@N05
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] Ha! Good call on the AUSTRAL, isn't it amazing you can gather that level of detail for its cargo? And all the different tenants of the surrounding buildings. [http://www.flickr.com/photos/51979177@N02] I am sure that McBurney link will come in handy some time... Like now! A new cause of confusion, perhaps the ship isn't LA HOGUE afterall? (The vessel was no longer part of the Australian trade route)
comment.authorname: Australian National Maritime Museum on The Commons

comment.author: 51979177@N02
comment._content: acms.sl.nsw.gov.au/item/itemLarge.aspx?itemID=414435 here's an interesting pic...looks like that lone building which later sported the Germea advert was around for years... acms.sl.nsw.gov.au/item/itemLarge.aspx?itemID=414373 the companion pic...which shows the Sydney Rowing Club boatshed etc which were at Bennelong Point in the period 1870-1888
